author: Shoumojit Banerjee
text:
The Marathi literary world received a shot in the arm on Monday with the Sahitya Akademi’s announcement in New Delhi that Pune-based author-translator Dr. Damodar Khadse had won an award in the Best Translation category.

Dr. Khadse has been awarded for his adroit translation of noted Marathi litterateur Sadanand Deshmukh’s visceral award-winning 2004 novel Baromas (Forever) — it deals with the plight of farmers in Vidarbha — into Hindi. Mr. Deshmukh himself was awarded the Sahitya Akademi for the book. “It was a challenge and a pleasure tackling Mr. Deshmukh’s complex book as I had to unravel the syntax written in a dialect spoken by the farmers of the Vidarbha region. I was in close consultation with Mr. Deshmukh as I wanted to render the rhythms and cadences of the novel as faithfully and flavourfully as possible,” said an ecstatic Dr. Khadse, who has more than 30 poetry and prose collections in Hindi to his name besides numerous renderings of Marathi works into Hindi.

“This will immeasurably help in foregrounding Marathi literature besides making a great novel accessible to vast multitudes of Hindi readers.”

One of his particularly noteworthy translations is that of Laxman Mane’s searing 1980 award-winning autobiographical work Upara (An Outsider), which is considered to be an iconic book in Marathi Dalit literature.
title: Pune author among 23 translators to be honoured by Sahitya Akademi
